rating_criteria.description: Spine conditions are rated based on range of motion limitation OR incapacitating episodes

general_rating_formula.description: General Rating Formula for Diseases and Injuries of the Spine (with or without symptoms such as pain, stiffness, or aching)

levels.criteria: Forward flexion of the thoracolumbar spine greater than 60 degrees but not greater than 85 degrees; OR combined range of motion greater than 120 degrees but not greater than 235 degrees; OR muscle spasm, guarding, or localized tenderness not resulting in abnormal gait or abnormal spinal contour

Forward flexion of the thoracolumbar spine greater than 30 degrees but not greater than 60 degrees; OR combined range of motion not greater than 120 degrees; OR muscle spasm or guarding severe enough to result in abnormal gait or abnormal spinal contour
Forward flexion of the thoracolumbar spine 30 degrees or less; OR favorable ankylosis of the entire thoracolumbar spine
Unfavorable ankylosis of the entire thoracolumbar spine
Unfavorable ankylosis of the entire spine

ivds_formula.description: Formula for Rating Intervertebral Disc Syndrome Based on Incapacitating Episodes
ivds_formula.note: An incapacitating episode is a period of acute signs and symptoms that requires bed rest prescribed by a physician and treatment by a physician

levels.criteria: Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 1 week but less than 2 weeks during the past 12 months
Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 2 weeks but less than 4 weeks during the past 12 months
Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 4 weeks but less than 6 weeks during the past 12 months
Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 6 weeks during the past 12 months

exam_sections: Range of Motion (ROM) and Functional Limitation

rom_testing.active_rom: Required - patient moves on their own
rom_testing.weight_bearing: Must test both weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing
rom_testing.flare_ups: Must estimate ROM during flare-ups based on all evidence

radiculopathy.description: Nerve root involvement causing pain/symptoms in lower extremities
radiculopathy.note: Radiculopathy of each lower extremity is rated separately under 38 CFR 4.124a

bowel_dysfunction.description: Loss of bowel control related to spine condition

bladder_dysfunction.description: Loss of bladder control related to spine condition

tips_for_veterans: Document your WORST days, not just average days
Describe specific limitations: how far can you bend, twist, lift?
Mention if you have flare-ups and how often they occur
Describe what triggers flare-ups and how long they last
Report ALL symptoms including radiating pain down legs (radiculopathy)
Mention if you have numbness, tingling, or weakness in legs
Document any bowel or bladder problems
Bring records of any incapacitating episodes requiring bed rest
If you use a cane, brace, or walker - tell the examiner
Explain how your back limits work activities and daily tasks
Don't push through pain during ROM testing - stop when it hurts
common_mistakes: Minimizing pain during the exam to appear strong
Not mentioning radiating leg pain (this can be rated separately)
Forgetting to describe flare-ups and their impact
Not mentioning incapacitating episodes requiring bed rest
Failing to document how condition affects work and daily life
Not bringing documentation of all treatment and medications
important_notes: Objective neurologic abnormalities (radiculopathy) are rated separately
Forward flexion is the most critical measurement for rating
Painful motion is functional limitation and should be considered
IVDS can be rated under either general formula OR incapacitating episodes - whichever is higher
Examiner MUST estimate ROM during flare-ups even if not observed
